title: Can we please put the "safe space" argument to rest?
body:
It's not relevant, and it's borderline political.

I highly doubt Riot is trying to create a "safe space" at least, not in the sense that people usually use the phrase. More often than not, I see people who throw around the "safe space" and "snowflake" rhetoric acting like they are victims of some kind of passive system. It just doesn't make sense to me, if you think league is a "safe space" then what pray tell is the opposite that you so desperately seem to strive for?

League is a game, and it's there for people to have fun. For ALL people to have fun, not just for flamers with no self-control. So if having fun for these people means attempting to ruin others' fun by making them feel miserable then I don't see why that should be allowed.

---

_Edit: I need to clarify something because people seem to think I'm arguing about whether or not Riot is making league a safe space. That's not what I'm arguing about._

> [{quoted}](name=HalcyonDweller,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=4N6LVtXe,comment-id=0008000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-29T20:57:57.139+0000)
>
> I'm against people who use "snowflakes" and "safe spaces" as excuses to blame Riot for their punishment instead of accepting responsibility for their own lack of self-control.
> 
> I didn't explain it very well in the original post, but it's better outlined in the comments, both [here](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/4N6LVtXe-can-we-please-put-the-safe-space-argument-to-rest?comment=00020001) and [here](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/4N6LVtXe-can-we-please-put-the-safe-space-argument-to-rest?comment=00030000)

_What I'm arguing about is that people come to the boards and make posts saying they (or someone else) didn't deserve to be punished and were only punished because league is being made into a "safe space" and because sjws and snowflakes are running amok. This is ridiculous, and the people who say this are usually just clinging to excuses to avoid questioning themselves or admitting that maybe they went a little too far with their behavior._

**_I'm all for having a discussion about how the punishment system needs improvement. But the moment you come to the boards making a post like "RIOT = SJWs" or other stupid stuff you kill the opportunity for us to have a productive discussion. You waste everyone's time, and you make yourself look like a fool._**

replies.body: But then you can just mute the people who ruin your fun?

I already do. This isn't just about me and my own gameplay.

What you just did there was shove the burden of responsibility entirely onto the people who get harassed. People like you often argue, saying "we can't be expected to always control our anger when people do truly infuriating things that piss us off!" **And honestly I agree** that you can't be expected to always keep your cool.

But your exact same argument can be used to defend people who get flamed too. They cannot be expected to always have the self-control and self-awareness necessary to simply mute someone who flames them. Everyone is human, they're at varying levels of development and varying levels of emotional control. You can't expect them to bear 100% of the burden of self-control and argue that flamers shouldn't also be held responsible too.

tldr; the problem is twofold, and the responsibility for it is shared. People should not be so easily offended, but just the same, "There is a mute button" is never an excuse to act like a very shitty person.
It's perfectly OK to get angry. What some don't seem to realize is that they do NOT have a right to act on that anger.

The burden of responsibility IS on the user.

They have the mute button.

They can either use it or stop being a bitch.

I appreciate good sass, but it's a moral and ethical burden. Obviously the physical act of muting someone is easier than most things, but when you take into consideration the self-control required it's a more even issue. Both the flamer and the flamee that gets offended are equally responsible for their failure to control themselves and for allowing their egos to take the wheel.

When I see people complain about flamers here I almost always advocate that they should (or should have) mute(d) the person who offended them. But that's still a hop, skip and a jump from claiming that the flamer wasn't responsible for their own loss of self-control.

> Anyways, 
> 
> Freedom for all is what I strive for. Basically it comes down to, "righteous" people don't want to let "toxic" people express freedom of speech. However, "toxic" people have no problem letting "righteous" people express freedom of speech. 
> 
> I personally prefer freedom because it is beneficial to EVERYONE. 

Freedom is great. However a lot of people misuse it to wrong others. When I was in gradeschool, a particular kid would often retaliate to things. he would escalate and escalate the situation, even when he couldn't see that he was the one who started it. "I'm just applying retribution" he'd say, when in reality the other person was the one who was taking retribution for what he had done. One day he pissed off the wrong girl in class and she wasn't having any of his shit, he took "retribution" one time too many and she stabbed him in the hand with a pencil.

tldr; people use freedom as an excuse to act as judge, jury, and executioner on others whom they think have wronged them. It only leads to trouble. Both kids in my story were in the wrong, but it wouldn't have been an issue at all if the boy hadn't had a tendency to always see himself in the right and always think he could and should take retribution against perceived wrongs.

> The punishment system is not fun for all. It does not benefit everyone. It solely benefits the "righteous" people. Only the "righteous" people have fun.
> 
> Now we understand why the "righteous" people are so against freedom. The punishment system is fun and benefits the "righteous" people.

As someone who thinks of himself as righteous, I disagree. I don't like or agree with the current punishment system, it has flaws, and it's methods are outdated, clunky, and excessive. That said, the behaviors that it punishes for, are for the most part worth punishing. People need to learn to not do those things, because they make the game worse for both themselves and others.

1. I think Riot should revamp the punishment system to give more leeway to the punished. But I won't go in-depth on that here because it's off topic for the thread.

2. I think that Riot should do more to teach others alternatives to flaming. Because there are lots of better ways to get what you want out of teammates, but people just don't know how or they take shit too personally and then try to seek retribution against their teammate when really that's just counterproductive to what they really want in the end, which is just a fun game where everyone plays their best and tries to win.

> responsible for their own loss of self-control.

It's not Riots or the communities responsibility to punish loss of self-control. This isn't "league of maintain perfect self-control". 

> Freedom is great. However a lot of people misuse it to wrong others.

It is impossible to misuse freedom. That is why "righteous" people are so scared by what "toxic" people might do.

> tldr; people use freedom as an excuse to act as judge, jury, and executioner on others whom they think have wronged them.

It's ok when Riot does it though, right? The "righteous" people are allowed to act as judge, jury, and executioner because the "righteous" people are FREE to do so.

Also in the ToS you gave riot to be judge jury and executioner, so why are you complaining about something you explicitly gave them the authority to do in their game?

You are right, its level of optimism and wishful thinking does lean on the overly optimistic side, but I think that is why it is so successful! People tend to have a set way of doing things, a set way of how they want things done, and little room to be able to have an open and fair conversation about it. Said another way, people tend to lash out at things that are unfamiliar and different, and blame it if everything doesn't go there way. Despite how we try to teach our children against it, it becomes a societal norm. The only way to combat that is to find someone having a bad day and blaming everyone else, give them a hug, and give them a cookie. First we have to calm them down, then we have to let them know that it isn't so bad, and you are willing to give something of yours to them to let them know that you are someone willing to do this for them.

That goes the same with playing. I often encounter players who are downright mean to me, but I approach it with the attitude that I would want to be given. Great job when they get the kill, excellent teamwork when they get the turret, and letting them know that its ok to die in game and that we'll get to the end together. Calm, cool, collected, you can influence a player who is having a bad game and beginning to tilt into someone that is willing to listen to you for the better, without directly trying to, thus affecting the game in a positive direction.

Why ? Because there is a functioning mute system and a report system if they immediately went too far. So let people go out of their way to say what they want so long as it isn't hate speech.  It really doesn't matter because just like they have the right to say what they want I have the right to mute them and keep playing my game while minding my own. EASY DAY. 

So the current system caters to willing victims and makes the game cater to the "Safe Space" idea which from a maximum playerbase standpoint is a sound business strategy. Yet it does cater to the "Safe Space" still when there are already tools at any player's disposal to prevent them from being affected by someone else's communicated bullcrap.

That's not how emotions work. Language is intended to elicit a response. That's how communication works and why language, posture and tone are structured the way they are. It's no more possible to control your emotions than it is to avoid flinching when someone goes to punch you in the face (even highly trained boxers "flinch", it's just been repurposed through long practice into a defensive maneuver).

While it is possible to _modulate your reaction_ to emotions, as Halcyon continues to point out, this is an unfair expectation to place on others. It's the moral equivalent to saying, "if you would just learn how to take a punch, I could hit you more and it would be okay."
